There wasn't a hint of -- in anything in this Court that that sort of that conduct was illegal in any way.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, there were hints from this Court, weren't there, in 1970?

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: In 1971, excuse me, that's Coolidge.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, how about Jones.

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: Jones was a nighttime entry, and the Court was very specific --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: When was Warden against Hayden decided?

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: Warden against Hayden was previous, but I think it's fair to say that it wasn't until -- wasn't it previous --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Yes, I think it was previous --

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: Yes.
But I think it's fair --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) to this case.

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: Well, I think it's fair to say --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, I had only asked you --

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: -- that it wasn't until your decision -- your decision in Coolidge --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You submit that there were no hints in the --

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: That -- that was a hint.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: So -- well, anyway this is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What if New York law have said -- what if the statute of New York had said in this state no warrants of any kind shall be required for any searches and seizures of any kind, and that the law --

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: There is no law enforcement official --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- had been clear for a hundred years?

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: There's no law enforcement official in this country who would not tell a police officer, I don't care what that statute says, you better watch out, this -- there's trouble ahead if you obey that statute.

If -- if these police officers had come to a group of law enforcement officials and professors of law and judges at that time and said, now, what should we do, shall we follow the statute, I think what those people would have said is absolutely, they -- I mean, it's the law, there's no --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you're -- you're employees, you're officers of the State of New York and that is the legislature of the State of New York.
That's very natural advice to give.
And -- so would it have also I guess with my hypothetical statute.

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: No, sir, not true.

If -- if for example, myself as a prosecutor, if a police officer came to me in that situation that you posited, I would say -- probably I would say don't follow the statute, but if I didn't say that, I would at least say you follow it at your risk, and that's -- I wouldn't have said that in 1970 in this situation, and I don't think anybody else would have said it either.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I didn't -- it doesn't apply to this case because they didn't go to any official.

turn.speaker: peter_l_zimroth
turn.label: Mr. Peter L. Zimroth
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Hellerstein, do you have --

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: I have nothing further, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, very well.
Thank you gentlemen --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Hellerstein, I have a question, Mr. Chief Justice, if I may.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: By all means.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you agree with him about how long it takes to get a warrant?

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: Oh, not at all.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I didn't think you did.

turn.speaker: william_e_hellerstein
turn.label: Mr. William E. Hellerstein
turn.text: First of all, just to answer that, Mr. Zimroth is talking within the context of our existing statutory framework that says because we only give you warrants when you commence a prosecution, you have to see the prosecutor.
But that's what this case -- this case is about, we are police officers, can get warrants without having to see the prosecutor as they do in those jurisdictions so we can.
That's a critical difference.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
We'll hear arguments next in Board of Education of New York --
